summary: An entertaining marriage of glam and gore
reviewText: Lollipop Chainsaw is one of those rare games that is a sheer spectacle, defined solely by its intoxicating imagery and firmly established tone. Games of this type, however, commonly tend to encounter that little problem when the gimmick of the shiny surface eventually wears off and the gameplay becomes responsible for reeling in players for the long haul. As most critics have already told many of you, the game is certainly not fantastic, but it really shouldn't be passed up either. Developed by Grasshopper Manufacture as a resulting collaboration of game designer Goichi Suda and filmmaker James Gunn, the game inevitably arrived amidst a sea of comparisons, whether they be Goichi Suda's games (Killer7, Shadows of the Damned, No More Heroes, not to mention his partial involvement in Super Smash Bros. Brawl) or Gunn's movies (Dawn of the Dead, Slither, Super). While this game certainly features dark, twisted undertones echoing both developers' respective creativities, I'll warn everyone beforehand that making too many comparisons to the spectacle that is Lollipop Chainsaw would be unwise. No, this game deserves to be analyzed in its own light, within the "confines" of its own bewildering, nonsensical universe.In a nutshell, the game is a mish-mash concoction of scantily clad cheerleaders, zombie apocalypse gore, and lots and lots of rainbows and sparkles. It treads a very unique line between bloody hack-and-slash and simplistic childlike glee. If its creative team didn't draw you in, its explosive concept most likely will. The concept is this: blonde, busty, lollipop-loving cheerleader Juliet Starling awakens on the morning of her eighteenth birthday only to discover the beginning of a zombie apocalypse in her town, as hordes of her classmates transform into the undead and roam the city in search of human flesh. Luckily for her, she just so happens to come from a family of professional zombie hunters, something she hasn't yet revealed to her not-so-long-term boyfriend Nick Carlyle. As she heads out to meet up with him this same morning, he's attacked and bitten by one of the zombies. In order to prevent him from becoming a living corpse himself, Juliet severs his body from the neck down and casts a spell to keep him alive as a disembodied head (a nifty trick she picked up via zombie hunting excursions past, surely). Armed with a keychain of her boyfriend's head and an enormous chainsaw adorned with pink hearts, Juliet sets out to defeat the zombies and find out who's behind all this apocalyptic brouhaha.The combat system is predominantly combo-based, as Juliet strings together various attacks to cripple the undead offenders. Cheerleading-themed pom-pom bashes and kicks make for swift, light attacks that can be quickly strung together to stun enemies, while heavy chainsaw slashes tend to be slower but deal heavier damage. The primary goal is to get zombies "groggy," at which point they'll be temporarily stunned as stars circle their heads, and become much more vulnerable to attack. Pom-pom and cheerleading attacks excel at getting zombies groggy or pushing them back, while chainsaw slashes are usually what finish them off. Each bloody slash of Juliet's chainsaw is accompanied by flurries of sparkles, rainbows, and hearts, a plucky and pretty hilarious contrast to the game's mega-violence. As you proceed through the game, defeat zombies and save citizens from zombie attacks, you'll be awarded gold and platinum coins, the in-game currency which can be used to purchase new combos and attacks, health or strength boosts, and more. You'll also collect various flavors of lollipops throughout the stages; you can hold five maximum at one time, as each one can instantly recover a portion of Juliet's health as needed.Juliet's chainsaw will eventually become adorned with new equipment and features, allowing her to perform different types of stunts and abilities for hacking up zombies. My personal favorite is the Chainsaw Dash, which allows her to sprint forward at full speed while mowing down zombies in her way, all the while using boost panels to make high jumps across platforms and collect coins and other goodies. You'll also eventually be able to use Nick's head to attack zombies, or even place it on headless zombie bodies to briefly gain control of them. Lollipop Chainsaw's boss battles are generally quite memorable, as punky, wild-haired "zombie rock gods" enter various phases and initiate wild attack patterns.As Juliet kills zombies, she builds star meter, displayed at the bottom left of the screen. Once it's filled, you can activate Star Soul mode at your leisure, at which point Juliet glows with a rainbowy light, temporarily gaining invincibility and super-strength, set giddily to the soundtrack of Toni Basil's "Mickey." Star Soul mode makes for some of the flashiest, most addictive gameplay offered here-it's a shame the feature is somewhat under-utilized. Another nice feature is "Sparkle Hunting," which activates when Juliet flashily destroys three or more zombies. This triggers a cutscene of Juliet within a glittering background, and you'll be awarded coins depending on how impressive your attack combo was (this also substantially boosts your score/rating). Star Soul mode and Sparkle Hunting oftentimes go hand in hand, as more devastating combos and damage outputs are easier when Star Soul is active.There are also a variety of options for customization, as you'll over time be able to change Juliet's outfits and even build the soundtrack playlist of your choosing as you play through the stages. The game's spunky soundtrack is among its brightest assets, featuring a cheeky blend of old-school pop, electro-punk and nu-metal. Mindless Self Indulgence, Skrillex, Sleigh Bells, MSTRKRFT, Dead or Alive, Joan Jett, and even 50's pop quartet The Chordettes are just some examples of the vast variety of musical acts you'll be enjoying throughout this game. The soundtrack compliments the extreme irony/silliness of the plot, and helps remind you that Lollipop Chainsaw never once requests to be taken seriously (important to remember, given that certain aspects of the game, particularly the heavy sexualizing of Juliet's character and the accompanying insults hurled her way by other characters, may offend certain players who aren't open to such humor; and be warned, you'll be seeing quite a bit of Juliet's chest and panties).While this should all sound like a great deal of joyous fun (which it mostly is), Lollipop Chainsaw's missteps can be quite glaring. The nastiest offenders are some of the awkwardly-designed mini-games, which you'll be forced to play through to advance through certain stages. Some of these diversions from the ordinary hack-and-slash gameplay can be fun and add some nice variety, but they're mostly obnoxious buzzkills that harshly stall the momentum. Some examples include weirdly-structured bouts of zombie-themed basketball and baseball, in which you have to destroy zombies in a specific way to score a certain amount of points within a brief time limit, or protect a base runner from oncoming zombies with a chainsaw machinegun that can be awfully hard to aim/control. What ultimately renders these mini-games big stinkers is the fact that you die if you lose, meaning your score and final stage rating can be totally screwed over not because you died at the hands of enemy attacks, but because you lost a wonky mini-game. These really should have been left out and at their worst are totally infuriating.Additionally, this game is comparatively speaking extremely short; the basic campaign should take most players only between five to eight hours total, and the replay factor can really dwindle from there, since there's no real online play or post-game content. However, the aforementioned end-of-stage ratings are uploaded to national leaderboards, so if you want to get really hardcore you do have the option of competing for the highest scores and see how you rank against other players (or Juliet's dad, the in-game `high score' standard). As previously mentioned, however, these rankings plummet if you die, meaning no matter how many zombies you defeat or goodies you sniff out and unlock, the mini-games can troll you into oblivion. Another of this game's biggest problems is its occasionally terrible camera angling-there's nothing worse than being cornered by hordes of enemies and suddenly having your screen view shift to a random close-up of a wall, which happens far more than it should here. You can manually move the camera, but there are times when you can't, and even when you can the movement tends to be slow, awkward and can be dangerously distracting in intense combat sequences.Speaking of the combat, although it can make for fluid fun and fantastic visuals, some players may notice that certain chainsaw attacks are slow and clunky, and some animations are required to finish before new attacks can be initiated, which can be a big problem in major zombie hordes. In addition to this, certain powerful combos aren't unlocked until near the game's end, many of which really should've just been available from the start to allow for wider variation from the simple, clunky attacks you'll have to rely on early on (which can ironically make the difficulty level go in reverse as you progressively have more to utilize). This certainly doesn't make or break the game, but it can take more getting used to than some may prefer, depending on personal play styles.Offsetting many of these flaws is the snappy script and dialogue; regardless of its ups and downs, a big goofy smile will be plastered on most players' faces throughout a vast majority of this game, not only because of the bedazzling aesthetics, but because much of the character banter is genuinely hilarious. Juliet somehow manages to be ditzy and witty all at the same time, while Nick is highly endearing as a wisecracking head; the two will banter continuously throughout the stages, and there's no shortage of random gags. Most of the characters are real gems as well, including Juliet's badass zombie-hunting sisters and the consistently entertaining zombie rock gods. The voice acting is also quite memorable, with Juliet being voiced by the well-known Tara Strong (Rugrats, Powerpuff Girls, Princess Mononoke, Teen Titans) and Michael Rosenbaum (Smallville, It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia, Batman Beyond) as Nick. The storyline, despite its absurdity, also comes together as something surely to develop into a major cult classic (I particularly liked the concept of the universe being split into three realms, and the explanation of the zombies escaping from the "Rotten World").As I said at the very beginning, this game is indeed a total spectacle, dedicated to blissful fun and entertainment, and that's what has to be understood from the get-go. Its sole purpose is to entertain and bewilder, and that it does very well. This game is designed for laughter and cheap thrills, of which it does offer many. Although it's arguably shorter and occasionally clunkier than it should be, it's such a wild, glitzy ride that it really has to be experienced by most gamers. I'm anticipating a big cult following and a great deal of cosplay inspiration to come. Who knew lollipops and chainsaws were such a nice match?

description: In Resident Evil 4 you'll know a new type of horror, as the classic survival-horror action returns with all-new characters, controls and storylines. We last saw Leon S. Kennedy in Resident Evil 2 - a rookie cop in Raccoon City, fighting to stay alive. That was six years ago. Since then, government forces have managed to control the zombie threat and Leon has become a Federal agent. When the President's daughter is kidnapped, Leon tracks her to a remote, hidden fortress in Europe - where he'll relive the horror he faced six years before.   Players will face never-before-seen enemies that make Nemesis seem like a kitten. You'll be wishing for the usual Resident Evil zombies!
reviewText: I won't lie to anyone. The game looks as good as any other RE game made. It looks great. But the controls system is the worst system I've ever used. I bought it for the PC because everyone knows that shooters work best on PC. Gamepads aren't accurate and a mouse is the way to go.There are NO control mapping abilities in the main menu. When you go to the controls screen, it only allows you to invert the aiming and switch aiming preset keys.The book is no better. It says what each key does but the game will tell you to run by pressing "3". "3" has nothing to do with running. the right ctrl button controls running. I found out the game meant "ENTER". I kept pressing it and then while running, it said press "5+6". "5+6" again, have nothing to do with what it wants you to do. I tried the number keys and the keypad. I tried finding what 5+6 meant on a keypad and use those keys on the keyboard. Nothing happened. I can't go any farther since I keep dieing.The website has ZERO help in the matter.I agree with the other rater that said the box lies and says a mouse is compatible. YEAH RIGHT!Great graphics - baaad gameplay.

description: Tomb Raider: Anniversary retraces Lara Croft's original genre-defining adventure, as she pursues the legendary Scion artifact. New graphics, technology and physics bring Lara's adventure up-to-date and offers gamers a completely new game play experience. Re-imagined, Anniversary delivers a dynamic fluidly and fast Lara Croft, massive environments of stunning visuals, intense combat and game pacing, and an enhanced and clarified original story. Enter into strange, undiscovered lands and solve their deepest, darkest mysteries, open doors to new realms, uncover great rewards and unearth secrets to Lara's past.
reviewText: After beating Tomb Raider Underworld I thought I'd give the PS2 versions a shot and I am one of the few who didn't like this game. The controls feel unresponsive when you have to make quick moves. The T-Rex boss battle was enough for me to quit. You can't dodge the guy very well. You are running backwards shooting trying to get him to charge into some spikes that you can't see behind you. I rarely just give up on a game but playing a boss battle for hours and not getting past that point ceases to be fun.

description: Grab the wheel of your airship and prepare to embark on an adventure of legendary proportions. You are Vyse, a young member of the Blue Rogue pirates. Together with your childhood friend Aika and a mysterious girl named Fina, you are locked in an epic struggle with a powerful enemy nation for the fate of the world. You must gather your own crew of air pirates and journey through uncharted skies to obliterate the empire from every corner of the map. Along the way you'll wage battles against savage monsters and evil pirates as you make a name for yourself on land and in the sky. For the first time you can experience the complete story of this critically acclaimed RPG, with hours of new gameplay containing additional background stories for key characters. Interact with a brilliantly animated cast of characters, monsters, and villains, explore astounding environments, and unravel a dramatic and twisting story line. You can explore six enormous virtual lands with landscapes ranging from massive deserts and quaint villages to the cold reaches of outer space. Customize your own airship and gather up to 22 crew members to help attack or protect against other ships. There is hand-to-hand and ship-to-ship combat featuring spectacular spell effects, amazing special attacks, and an improved battle engine.
reviewText: In this game you play as Vyse and his friends young air pirates on a quest to stop Valua a evil empire from getting six moon crystals each controlling a creature so powerful it could take over the sky/world. To do this you must go from solving puzzles to escaping burning buildings you also must make some choices. Air pirates are split into two groups Blue Rouges and Black Pirates Vyse is a Blue Rouge. This game is hard just not too hard!

description: Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare,the new action thriller from the award-winning team at Infinity Ward, the creators of the Call of Duty series, delivers the most intense and cinematic action experience ever.Armed with an arsenal of advanced and powerful modern-day firepower, players are transported to treacherous hotspots around the globe to take on a rogue enemy group threatening the world. As both a U.S. Marine and British S.A.S. soldier fighting through an unfolding story full of twists and turns, players use sophisticated technology, superior firepower, and coordinated land and air strikes on a battlefield where speed, accuracy, and communication are essential to victory.The epic title also delivers an added depth of multiplayer action providing online fans an all-new community of persistence, addictive, and customizable gameplay.Features:Authentic advanced weaponry: Featuring an available arsenal of more than 70 new and authentic weapons and gear from assault rifles with laser sites, claymore mines, .50 caliber sniper rifles, and M-249 SAW machine guns. With accessories like night-vision goggles and ghillie suits for maximum concealment,Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfarehas players locked and loaded to accomplish the mission.Coordinated assault and support: Delivering the most visceral action thriller ever, the title covers modern battle from the soldier to the satellite, where the need for air support is critical to success. The adrenaline rush deployment enlists gamers to fast-rope from tactical helicopters, ride in an armada of attack choppers, utilize jets to remove enemy strongholds, and even engage hostiles from thousands of feet above the ground inside a state-of-the-art aerial gunship.Cinematic-quality graphics and sound: Featuring stunning next-generation graphics, players will be drawn into the cinematic intensity ofCall of Duty 4: Modern Warfare.Amazing special effects, including realistic depth of field, rim-lighting, character self-shadowing, texture streaming, as well as physics-enabled effects, will enlist players into the most photo-realistic gaming experience. Combine the lifelike graphics and the realistic battle chatter with the Call of Duty award-winning sound design and players will face battle as they never have before.Unparalleled depth to multiplayer: Multiplayer builds from the success ofCall of Duty 2delivering a persistent online experience for greater community interaction. Featuring create-a-class options allowing players to customize gear that is best suited for play, to experience points enabling unlockables and perks, all the way to matchmaking and leaderboards for the latest in tracking,Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare'smultiplayer is set to deliver easily accessible and addictive online play for all.

summary: Quit using the F bomb already!
reviewText: OK.  So here is the deal.  I'm a gamer.  I'm an older gamer that now has kids that like to game.  Yes, we have several family friendly games, and then we have some M rated games like COD.  So I expect violence and a fair share of it when I play it.  What really throws me for a loop is the amount of profanity in the game.  Yes, I know it is disclosed on the box and that way parents can make an "informed" decision.  I'm starting to think now that I would like to see how many times a specific profanity word is used. Parents let me tell you, in this game, the F bomb is used a lot.  Enough to catch my attention and I've used it a fair amount in my earlier days.So bash me all you want about letting my 14 year old see this kind of violence and yet I'm worried about the language.  Actually, I think most kids understand that the violence they see on screen is completely fake and doesn't translate into the real world.  Let's give our kids some credit for that.  Words, however, are a different story.  That language is used by some everyday and not used by others.  However, the constant repetition of the F bomb, over and over is completely over the top and useless in the game.  It adds absolutely nothing to the story.  Zero.From a game standpoint, it is a decent game.  Graphics are good, AI seems to a bit more difficult and you get thrown into a lot of different situations rather than just being boots on the ground.  It was however, a little difficult to follow along with what was actually playing out.So my plea to developers is if you can have an option to tone down the violence (gore, etc), do the same for the language.  It can't be that hard to program in.

reviewText: I know they want to build a story, but they have way too many of them ! And most of the time you CANNOT SKIP THEM.
